4EAC2146E9724D96962969631985B95E.description: Know that some polyesters, known as biopolyesters, are biodegradable

3B2797234A46465AA32CACC03351061D.description:
Understand how to write the structural and displayed formula of a polyester,
showing the repeat unit, given the formulae of the monomers from which it
is formed including the reaction of ethanedioic acid and ethanediol.

BF7EBFBD49A542BE8C469E35FDC44581.description:
Know that condensation polymerisation, in which a dicarboxylic acid reacts
with a diol, produces a polyester and water

49EB7BC1FF87459685558452F975FE73.description: Explain problems in the disposal of addition polymers, including:  their inertness and inability to biodegrade; the production of toxic gases when they are burned

4CDEF03386D64A5A931C16E613752FF7.description:
Understand how to deduce the structure of a monomer from the repeat unit of an
addition polymer and vice versa

14C4585521D242389DB4B893BB3B0464.description:
Understand how to draw the repeat unit of an addition polymer, including
poly(ethene), poly(propene), poly(chloroethene) and (poly)tetrafluoroethene

8A964A70F10A4C9C9848635382CBDDB1.description:
Know that an addition polymer is formed by joining up many small molecules called
monomers

382D274592264A479AE9EB58C3DF93DE.description: Practical: prepare a sample of an ester such as ethyl ethanoate

4209BDE1B0804554BBC2506AF3AB33C3.description:
Know that esters are volatile compounds with distinctive smells and are used
as food flavourings and in perfumes

2E16F9B5040E4D588B5563DC74C31EBB.description:
Understand how to write the structural and displayed formulae of an ester,
given the name or formula of the alcohol and carboxylic acid from which it is
formed and vice versa

61597A0F8E7C48DC89DC58AD7A7A9FE1.description:
Understand how to write the structural and displayed formulae of
ethyl ethanoate

96D4D5B8C66842A2A7CFD27D754D1BCE.description:
Know that ethyl ethanoate is the ester produced when ethanol and ethanoic
acid react in the presence of an acid catalyst

BAF69EB8DCFF4730AD4AA41366AAD614.description: Know the functional group of an ester

9623CC9576404CC5B498A0E732933CBD.description: Know that vinegar is an aqueous solution containing ethanoic acid

E5DCA2178BDA486190217AE79C576188.description:
Describe the reactions of aqueous solutions of carboxylic acids with metals
and metal carbonates

CEB99FB7920C410F99EE7242CECF62BF.description:
Understand how to draw structural and displayed formulae for
unbranched-chain carboxylic acids with up to four carbon atoms in the
molecule, and name each compound

0E39890EBAC042B9AC9EF6B7980E9AD3.description: Know the functional group of a carboxylic acids

786421807B504B13A54674BDD7CAD97E.description:
Understand the reasons for fermentation, in the absence of air, and at an
optimum temperature

4ABC26027F1F444688678839396BAD7E.description:
Know that ethanol can be manufactured by: reacting ethene with steam in the presence of a phosphoric acid catalyst
at a temperature of about 300 ºC and a pressure of about 60–70 atm;  the fermentation of glucose, in the absence of air, at an optimum
temperature of about 30 ºC and using the enzymes in yeast

C1194C9BE8414005808E9319B42B9AD6.description:
Know that ethanol can be oxidised by: burning in air or oxygen (complete combustion); reaction with oxygen in the air to form ethanoic acid
(microbial oxidation); heating with potassium dichromate(VI) in dilute sulfuric acid to form
ethanoic acid

D60860E766B24CE8867AE13134F6CA93.description:
Understand how to draw structural and displayed formulae for methanol,
ethanol, propanol (propan-1-ol only) and butanol (butan-1-ol only), and
name each compound
the names propanol and butanol are acceptable

F0F0F92E9DA64A0EBD202058A0308FA7.description: Know that alcohols contain the functional group −OH

1C2F679ACC6F4935BE2F86C93DABDD8D.description:
Describe how bromine water can be used to distinguish between an alkane and an
alkene

EAA189DE409E40FF85E00408D1175CB3.description: Describe the reactions of alkenes with bromine to produce dibromoalkanes

9E94CAF5C74D4D47927657ADC896813B.description:
Understand how to draw the structural and displayed formulae for alkenes with up to
four carbon atoms in the molecule, and name the unbranched-chain isomers

CEC3744B099C457D8FF96D975AEB278F.description: Explain why alkenes are classified as unsaturated hydrocarbons

18477261343C4C2FAF287CC44EC0B585.description: Know the general formula for alkenes

CA1F1B685DFE4C51BC61EA55FA52F7FB.description: Know that alkenes contain the functional group >C=C<

E1B80D5054F74FFAB62C270A6FCF8894.description:
Describe the reactions of alkanes with halogens in the presence of ultraviolet
radiation, limited to mono-substitution
knowledge of reaction mechanisms is not required

BE2376028E7546939C877A40C7273313.description:
Understand how to draw the structural and displayed formulae for alkanes with up to
five carbon atoms in the molecule, and to name the unbranched-chain isomers

F316DC1DE8564AECB6BCF18E58E6DB6D.description: Explain why alkanes are classified as saturated hydrocarbons

084BAC93DFF346B8AECEF6CDDFD656EC.description: Know the general formula for alkanes

0BBE920CE0CE4CC58690BF9CBD6C83DC.description:
Explain why cracking is necessary, in terms of the balance between supply and
demand for different fractions

4E0F622812CE4D099FA7F3BE652017AA.description:
Describe how long-chain alkanes are converted to alkenes and shorter-chain alkanes
by catalytic cracking (using silica or alumina as the catalyst and a temperature in the
range of 600–700 ºC)

E9DCBC5ACC3445D6B2D8D32DB2F09A7B.description: Understand how sulfur dioxide and oxides of nitrogen contribute to acid rain

8B75DA0E2FD44997A95B0704687F4575.description:
Explain how the combustion of some impurities in hydrocarbon fuels results in the
formation of sulfur dioxide

AE3D2F44B10F41008F6B5718CFE2AD0D.description:
Know that, in car engines, the temperature reached is high enough to allow nitrogen
and oxygen from air to react, forming oxides of nitrogen

0E3AFF16507F4DBDA45D57B2EB56D93E.description:
Understand why carbon monoxide is poisonous, in terms of its effect on the capacity
of blood to transport oxygen
references to haemoglobin are not required

8C6DAE3203DE4282AF562CC0848EF998.description:
Know the possible products of complete and incomplete combustion of hydrocarbons
with oxygen in the air

1965B013F0844773B660FAB34A5DA937.description: Know that a fuel is a substance that, when burned, releases heat energy

483036FBF2384CA69930820D37B07EB8.description: Know the trend in colour, boiling point and viscosity of the main fractions

4BE6260C4F814A8AB35011AB79F61655.description:
Know the names and uses of the main fractions obtained from crude oil:
refinery gases, gasoline, kerosene, diesel, fuel oil and bitumen

A3D36F9A61A74B36A774BAFE99273F37.description:
Describe how the industrial process of fractional distillation separates crude oil into
fractions

A9D2C59A84B143519B1C9B5ADEFE6CAF.description: Know that crude oil is a mixture of hydrocarbons

DB7134F56A014BE1812C7A1586562A6D.description:
Understand how to classify reactions of organic compounds as substitution, addition
and combustion
knowledge of reaction mechanisms is not required

BEF3407BDAB2401AB47C5D952AA90BFC.description:
Understand how to write the possible structural and displayed formulae of an organic
molecule given its molecular formula

46D8180E761045C8A16B5802D83E2D96.description:
Understand how to name compounds relevant to this specification using the rules of
International Union of Pure and Applied Chemistry (IUPAC) nomenclature
students will be expected to name compounds containing up to six carbon atoms

652D78E0E19D4D6E8843FD66C35A93F4.description: Know what is meant by the terms homologous series, functional group and isomerism

555742900A91471AA598641CD698EA02.description:
Understand how to represent organic molecules using empirical formulae, molecular
formulae, general formulae, structural formulae and displayed formulae

4F57C236D43846A7A3E871452A089EBE.description: Know that a hydrocarbon is a compound of hydrogen and carbon only

AD1C53218EE34DF6A51D1EC6FA6BDD51.description:
Know the effect of changing either temperature or pressure on the position
of equilibrium in a reversible reaction: an increase (or decrease) in temperature shifts the position of
equilibrium in the direction of the endothermic (or exothermic) reaction; an increase (or decrease) in pressure shifts the position of equilibrium in
the direction that produces fewer (or more) moles of gas
References to Le Chatelier's principle are not required

024052507BC94FB48D28F73FD620B3EC.description:
Understand why a catalyst does not affect the position of equilibrium in a
reversible reaction

5F7411E2496549AA97BAB61451D0EB61.description: Know that the characteristics of a reaction at dynamic equilibrium are: the forward and reverse reactions occur at the same rate; the concentrations of reactants and products remain constant.

BC066E513FD04915954F61FC07071C9A.description:
Know that a reversible reaction can reach dynamic equilibrium in a sealed
container

8438F28E3291488B9719D65E06A88316.description:
Describe reversible reactions such as the dehydration of hydrated copper(II) sulfate
and the effect of heat on ammonium chloride

0EFAB47D09BF4ADEA9FB8C495D87FA53.description:
Know that some reactions are reversible and this is indicated by the symbol ⇌ in
equations

CD6A067B075743EFB4827A73CE3B5D2B.description:
Practical: investigate the effect of different solids on the catalytic decomposition of
hydrogen peroxide solution

5BB4693BCCD941DF9657E07E051CBF67.description:
Practical: investigate the effect of changing the surface area of marble chips and of
changing the concentration of hydrochloric acid on the rate of reaction between
marble chips and dilute hydrochloric acid

CF70E892F88F4B34986534B7D642BD88.description:
Draw and explain reaction profile diagrams showing ΔH and activation
energy

13AE98B80FB44189AFF19EDB861F548B.description:
Know that a catalyst works by providing an alternative pathway with lower activation
energy

A66D8A1459C44219B6DF3EC975258F11.description:
Know that a catalyst is a substance that increases the rate of a reaction, but is
chemically unchanged at the end of the reaction

9480A9408FBE4AF7A0F2555C9E48618A.description:
Explain the effects of changes in surface area of a solid, concentration of a solution,
pressure of a gas and temperature on the rate of a reaction in terms of particle
collision theory

BC5A7280053F43B4BE9A4C04DB20A0DF.description:
Describe the effects of changes in surface area of a solid, concentration of a solution,
pressure of a gas, temperature and the use of a catalyst on the rate of a reaction

6FB47E096E9B445E8B573BC41FB3C867.description:
Describe experiments to investigate the effects of changes in surface area of a solid,
concentration of a solution, temperature and the use of a catalyst on the rate of a
reaction

3A6BA0CCE2F04A8DB4E2411B186FBDDA.description:
Practical: investigate temperature changes accompanying some of the following types
of change: salts dissolving in water, neutralisation reactions, displacement reactions, combustion reactions.

F8680FDB0B5C4A7080777326004407A2.description:
Use bond energies to calculate the enthalpy change during a chemical
reaction

26AB1F967D86480FB450D25EC7B768B8.description:
Know that bond-breaking is an endothermic process and that bond-making is
an exothermic process

557D13790F86460DAA1A5549730E5108.description:
Draw and explain energy level diagrams to represent exothermic and
endothermic reactions

A17F6B95171E4F81B0836493759BBD4E.description: Calculate the molar enthalpy change (ΔH) from the heat energy change, Q

6C073852E3154137A9665B4959FA7DBC.description:
Calculate the heat energy change from a measured temperature change using the
expression Q = mcΔT

7E65198225A342CF80F4C88A977F7190.description:
Describe simple calorimetry experiments for reactions such as combustion,
displacement, dissolving and neutralisation

0467DDDC4F4849A0B30AD6C45752306A.description:
Know that chemical reactions in which heat energy is given out are described as
exothermic, and those in which heat energy is taken in are described as endothermic

2E3EE6E4F747401AAE38D6D6A699D6C1.description: Describe a physical test to show whether a sample of water is pure

1E89F7BF580F41BC93D67907290F9E77.description: Describe a test for the presence of water using anhydrous copper(II) sulfate

C3FBE3EAE9AA4E60A3C120E911BD99BA.description: Describe tests for these anions:  Cl–, Br– and I– using acidified silver nitrate solution; SO42– using acidified barium chloride solution; CO32– using hydrochloric acid and identifying the gas evolved.

F61C99D4A0794070940B15179FDD5E0A.description: Describe tests for these cations: NH4+ using sodium hydroxide solution and identifying the gas evolved; Cu2+, Fe2+ and Fe3+ using sodium hydroxide solution.

922B8A47F2A1417280D1F2FFC4618B5E.description: Know the colours formed in flame tests for these cations: Li+ is red; Na+ is yellow; K+ is lilac; Ca2+ is orange-red; Cu2+ is blue-green.

C752779F8C144BD1BE8AC7BE1AC8E2E7.description: Describe how to carry out a flame test

7805A2859C864A4CABF9F860BE597959.description: Describe tests for these gases: hydrogen, oxygen, carbon dioxide, ammonia, chlorine.

AE709A62ABA24036A22303B11D5B25DB.description: Practical: prepare a sample of pure, dry lead(II) sulfate

8DA1457F9933423A9DB9A6115A6805B1.description:
Practical: prepare a sample of pure, dry hydrated copper(II) sulfate crystals starting
from copper(II) oxide

5707E8573B3B436196C2BF688AC85C4C.description:
Describe an experiment to prepare a pure, dry sample of an insoluble salt,
starting from two soluble reactants

8FBEDBFAC8134E02A3B61799B0DD4A0B.description:
Describe an experiment to prepare a pure, dry sample of a soluble salt,
starting from an acid and alkali

5112EC5FDC724F24B9BF1502EDB67558.description:
Describe an experiment to prepare a pure, dry sample of a soluble salt, starting from
an insoluble reactant

52B2CCCCBE424C43A0402B5B8E952301.description:
Know that metal oxides, metal hydroxides and ammonia can act as bases, and that
alkalis are bases that are soluble in water

D870B67942AD45FDBE16B0B0914B4579.description:
Describe the reactions of hydrochloric acid, sulfuric acid and nitric acid with metals,
bases and metal carbonates (excluding the reactions between nitric acid and metals)
to form salts

381D1E124BE1417E80B2F9E6FA16D56D.description: Understand that an acid is a proton donor and a base is a proton acceptor

A8C0C331DF674D17B01BAD291A46C168.description: Understand acids and bases in terms of proton transfe

8E94803DC4A44E6F9BEDEB67A35C7916.description:
Know the general rules for predicting the solubility of ionic compounds in water: common sodium, potassium and ammonium compounds are soluble; all nitrates are soluble; common chlorides are soluble, except those of silver and lead(II); common sulfates are soluble, except for those of barium, calcium and lead(II); common carbonates are insoluble, except for those of sodium, potassium and
ammonium; common hydroxides are insoluble except for those of sodium, potassium and
calcium (calcium hydroxide is slightly soluble).

01F422D845D34BD58BC8EF155576A56D.description: Describe how to carry out an acid-alkali titration

D95AFE9EF4974A69B04BF6C22C1F4A60.description: Know that alkalis can neutralise acids

74C03DF7109A4CCE8ACDC447E04AF7CA.description:
Know that acids in aqueous solution are a source of hydrogen ions and alkalis in a
aqueous solution are a source of hydroxide ions

4B6F8D1E1ECE46019DDB1AC35A83561E.description:
Describe the use of universal indicator to measure the approximate pH value of an
aqueous solution

038FB248C6754307A404053B11080779.description:
Understand how to use the pH scale, from 0–14, can be used to classify solutions as
strongly acidic (0–3), weakly acidic (4–6), neutral (7), weakly alkaline (8–10) and
strongly alkaline (11–14)

727B6D1485AA4A1EA70F12E97E484388.description:
Describe the use of litmus, phenolphthalein and methyl orange to distinguish between
acidic and alkaline solutions

ADA3321A99604FFC94249B974399A3CA.description: Explain why alloys are harder than pure metals

8B550C8A1BF24863905A3C91829B9B15.description:
Know that an alloy is a mixture of a metal and one or more elements, usually
other metals or carbon

BD178DDCCC114455B4C289AB3FCD9F57.description:
Explain the uses of aluminium, copper, iron and steel in terms of their
properties
the types of steel will be limited to low-carbon (mild), high-carbon and
stainless

35AA0E464E4F4EAEBBBBFF3903F73E9B.description:
Be able to comment on a metal extraction process, given appropriate
information
detailed knowledge of the processes used in the extraction of a specific
metal is not required

F2390B483A524C548A8BB4EDDF8D0BE7.description:
Explain how the method of extraction of a metal is related to its position in
the reactivity series, illustrated by carbon extraction for iron and electrolysis
for aluminium

87B1A6E67CED450D962DFFC68F63122A.description:
Know that most metals are extracted from ores found in the Earth’s crust
and that unreactive metals are often found as the uncombined element

E21CA54F32244A3CB5E75DB9FE504DA4.description:
Practical: investigate reactions between dilute hydrochloric and sulfuric acids and
metals (e.g. magnesium, zinc and iron)

960851D33F044C30ABDF65E9BE9DEB6E.description:
Understand the terms: oxidation, reduction, redox, oxidising agent, reducing agent
in terms of gain or loss of oxygen and loss or gain of electrons

2760E42CD224415789D8B1DE683183F4.description: Understand how the rusting of iron may be prevented by: barrier methods, galvanising, sacrificial protection.

DB8F6F9BD54540E18590EF64D3FC43A8.description: Know the conditions under which iron rusts

E72ECC85D3434E01A2A900F07B1654DB.description:
Know the order of reactivity of these metals: potassium, sodium, lithium, calcium,
magnesium, aluminium, zinc, iron, copper, silver, gold

10DA6A510F444BC9AF27F2CB6EB4ED50.description:
Understand how metals can be arranged in a reactivity series based on their
displacement reactions between: metals and metal oxides; metals and aqueous solutions of metal salts.

2C50F7A08BD74CBFBAD1D1FB939C0E05.description:
Understand how metals can be arranged in a reactivity series based on their reactions
with:  water, dilute hydrochloric or sulfuric acid.

68978848350F434A92151239DF405AB6.description:
Practical: determine the approximate percentage by volume of oxygen in air using a
metal or a non-metal

07730469FD2E47B38A09CB154917DCF6.description:
Know that carbon dioxide is a greenhouse gas and that increasing amounts in the
atmosphere may contribute to climate change

82EB395A01FA4F27BA6FAF4506F2CD61.description:
Describe the formation of carbon dioxide from the thermal decomposition of metal
carbonates, including copper(II) carbonate

F4A8F6F0611E4410A3AB74FCD43EC07B.description:
Describe the combustion of elements in oxygen, including magnesium, hydrogen and
sulfur

451C42215D8944229699C704FF8140F6.description:
Understand how to determine the percentage by volume of oxygen in air using
experiments involving the reactions of metals (e.g. iron) and non-metals
(e.g. phosphorus) with air

999B6C4CA2DD4AD68BD0D4071AD6915F.description:
Know the approximate percentages by volume of the four most abundant gases in dry
air

35F0F6F38D8D4CACBD73134A4F5388E8.description:
Explain the trend in reactivity in Group 7 in terms of electronic
configurations

3E1A75DC3A904A64A63132F981618607.description:
Understand how displacement reactions involving halogens and halides provide
evidence for the trend in reactivity in Group 7

5D232DE420934CCCA779D830419B6C5D.description: Use knowledge of trends in Group 7 to predict the properties of other halogens

BC92322C96F14F8BAF35D1E21AA3B2D2.description:
Know the colours, physical states (at room temperature) and trends in physical
properties of these elements

014C0C2D33844FAC98FEDA4F2CCD87A4.description:
Explain the trend in reactivity in Group 1 in terms of electronic
configurations

97C5E71639894B20880FC8F33B645641.description: Use knowledge of trends in Group 1 to predict the properties of other alkali metals

12EB3A84835F46CFA04C14407A2ECE2E.description:
Understand how the differences between the reactions of these elements with air and
water provide evidence for the trend in reactivity in Group 1

F800F4E83ECD4185A0883488F9884A56.description:
Understand how the similarities in the reactions of these elements with water provide
evidence for their recognition as a family of elements

DDBC25F69F7648EDB4A82C787F81BC4B.description: Group 1 (Alkali Metals)- Lithium, Sodium and Potassium

9BEF1AAE50044EE492DB93151EB9CA48.description: Practical: investigate the electrolysis of aqueous solutions

3FEF04F04A3940899A3843DBEEA819E9.description:
Write ionic half-equations representing the reactions at the electrodes during
electrolysis and understand why these reactions are classified as oxidation
or reduction

C0BBA883B95740D98F217CF236A68F43.description:
Describe experiments to investigate electrolysis, using inert electrodes, of
molten compounds (including lead(II) bromide) and aqueous solutions
(including sodium chloride, dilute sulfuric acid and copper(II) sulfate) and to
predict the products

723CD8057E594E0FBEC002B3704E3899.description:
Know that anion and cation are terms used to refer to negative and positive
ions respectively

61EC5EB3A29B41A69F8B2C3276C97B67.description:
Understand why ionic compounds conduct electricity only when molten or in
aqueous solution

40AC3943C2B84C0B89E1D823E57A9D56.description: Understand why covalent compounds do not conduct electricity

C6BD1497C6194F8F9A787214DE6C4DCD.description:
Explain typical physical properties of metals, including electrical conductivity
and malleability

62A6B5AA125C4CD09F700EDC549AE891.description: Understand metallic bonding in terms of electrostatic attractions

BFEE154240A14F7DBC5E5501C0D268F0.description: Know how to represent a metallic lattice by a 2-D diagram

69439CFDCE28489F8FC883F9B5ADDA36.description: Know that covalent compounds do not usually conduct electricity

E8C6A9F011414191B6B62E43A71F8FFA.description:
Explain how the structures of diamond, graphite and C60 fullerene influence their
physical properties, including electrical conductivity and hardness

04B0EF71F0F240CFA61559DF304D48A9.description:
Explain why the melting and boiling points of substances with simple molecular
structures increase, in general, with increasing relative molecular mass

EB4AAE951D3F4CDFB098D70D59F2A3DD.description:
Explain why the melting and boiling points of substances with simple molecular
structures increase, in general, with increasing relative molecular mass

E55EED9016FC4171ADCC82BAFDE316D0.description:
Explain why substances with a simple molecular structures are gases or liquids, or
solids with low melting and boiling points
the term intermolecular forces of attraction can be used to represent all forces
between molecules

163C9E42AEB8472DB4EAC4318261EA4E.description:
Understand how to use dot-and-cross diagrams to represent covalent bonds in:  diatomic molecules, including hydrogen, oxygen, nitrogen, halogens and hydrogen
halides; inorganic molecules including water, ammonia and carbon dioxide; organic molecules containing up to two carbon atoms, including methane, ethane,
ethene and those containing halogen atoms.

CBE7610D339E444E8B1845FB975A3946.description: Understand covalent bonds in terms of electrostatic attractions

2A60286010BD49DB9D6727FA0649E7ED.description:
Know that a covalent bond is formed between atoms by the sharing of a pair of
electrons

FBC9C9792F0C4D1EB99B006759FC0DBE.description:
Know that ionic compounds do not conduct electricity when solid, but do conduct
electricity when molten and in aqueous solution

F02DE2D091C64C5B8EB76466870F9859.description:
Understand why compounds with giant ionic lattices have high melting and boiling
points

BB26910988FA4DC5A2DC70D6C93E5237.description: Understand ionic bonding in terms of electrostatic attractions

A65F7663253541D6B9B34226F79A4864.description:
Draw dot-and-cross diagrams to show the formation of ionic compounds by electron
transfer, limited to combinations of elements from Groups 1, 2, 3 and 5, 6, 7 (only outer electrons need be shown)

100C8D1FDCB74851B4E26F33834753F6.description: Write formulae for compounds formed between the ions listed above

39A802CAB2AC48FB824F87D63144661E.description: Understand how ions are formed by electron loss or gain

C96647F0842B4FBFB185112E419988EA.description:
Practical: know how to determine the formula of a metal oxide by combustion
(e.g. magnesium oxide) or by reduction (e.g. copper(II) oxide)

02464CC3A6EC4E94BB3D02B56A79955D.description:
Understand how to carry out calculations involving gas volumes and the
molar volume of a gas (24 dm3 and 24 000 cm3 at room temperature and
pressure (rtp))

41992A5596A54757962F1324D7ABE6AC.description:
Understand how to carry out calculations involving amount of substance,
volume and concentration (in mol/dm3) of solution

FEA9744A488C48BAB89FE61D912A797F.description: Calculate empirical and molecular formulae from experimental data

2493EEB26797490B94EE3660BB7B7FB6.description: Know what is meant by the terms empirical formula and molecular formula

935CCA9762BC45C3986CFEDA95ADF584.description:
Understand how the formulae of simple compounds can be obtained experimentally,
including metal oxides, water and salts containing water of crystallisation

50281199EE1B40278273F456890CB2C4.description: Calculate reacting masses using experimental data and chemical equations

41F44DB2FCB142109FCB211064AE6BD3.description:
Understand how to carry out calculations involving amount of substance, relative
atomic mass (Ar) and relative formula mass (Mr)

5DFC739539A2485FAAC05C359FA5CFBA.description: Know that the mole (mol) is the unit for the amount of a substance

3A1B248229824E90A04895DF29756002.description:
Calculate relative formula masses (including relative molecular masses) (Mr) from
relative atomic masses (Ar)

313FB4E5FF2742468B760E863289B609.description: Write word equations and balanced chemical equations (including state symbols):  for reactions studied in this specification; for unfamiliar reactions where suitable information is provided

6232863C79294599B77C04FCF65B4E02.description: Understand why the Noble Gases (Group 0) do not readily react

C583F4CAC7FA45C492DCDBAA0F5D7F99.description: Understand why elements in the same group of the Periodic Table have similar chemical properties

811D3B33FCD24CCBA3282A6074369AE1.description: Understand how the electronic configuration of a main group element is related to its position in the Periodic Table

800347F42C334F6D8384C75AB19A129E.description: Identify an element as a metal or a non-metal according to its position in the Periodic Table

0820B65226DB4DD4B3DCF823FA6531D5.description: Understand how to use electrical conductivity and the acid-base character to classify elements as metals or non-metals

43935DB4208446DDA50E4852679906E7.description: Understand how to deduce the electronic configurations of the first 20 elements from their positions in the Periodic Table

5DE1C0CE17F847F78C6B5903F8FB0F96.description: Understand how elements are arranged in the Periodic Table

02E32B2F8179429E995802C52361F6CA.description: Be able to calculate the relative atomic mass of an element (Ar) from isotopic abundances

3664F14D6BA84004B556D00363AFBD2F.description: Know what is meant by the terms atomic number, mass number, isotopes and relative atomic mass (Ar)

02D7DAC90C804B359501259892DC0E58.description: Know the structure of an atom in terms of the positions, relative masses and relative charges of sub-atomic particles

2EC451657D684F38A654B69CB7215320.description: Know what is meant by the terms atom and molecule

742E0BC91A254579984431DA39C0E268.description: Practical: investigate paper chromatography using inks/food colourings

29DB1BC6DAEF4B84B9DAE9A474BAF083.description: Understand how to use the calculation of Rf values to identify the components of a mixture

E43A3B8CADA6480EA17991AFA1DD2865.description: Understand how a chromatogram provides information about the composition of a mixture

09C28E8C8F7443E7ADA236FB270305FB.description: Describe these experimental techniques for the separation of mixtures: simple distillation, fractional distillation, filtration, crystallisation, paper chromatography.

165FE0C90BD346CDBBFD9C1AAA8362A1.description: Understand that a pure substance has a fixed melting and boiling point, but that a mixture may melt or boil over a range of temperatures

7C1825FFC4DB44B787522263AC9C42FE.description: Understand how to classify a substance as an element, compound or mixture

3CCAE062DB79455D9405FA9A043049BD.description: Practical: investigate the solubility of a solid in water at a specific temperature

847C5FA905A54D07A5ACCA72584AF4E6.description: Understand how to plot and interpret solubility curves

327A11BD1B1B433BB90C5F966FC037A2.description: Know what is meant by the term solubility in the units g per 100g of solvent

BD5D14419D9243069AF69EE7B8C6422F.description: Know what is meant by the terms: solvent, solute, solution, saturated solutio

AAB887310AA04355A65F67E9312B1D43.description: Understand how the results of experiments involving the dilution of coloured substances and diffusion of gases can be explained

025AC82B582448D6AE4C59FE319BBE65.description: Understand the interconversions between the three states of matter in terms of: the names of the interconversions; how they are achieved; the changes in arrangement, movement and energy of the particles

54603294764D4904AEC5D58B74BA2B25.description: Understand the three states of matter in terms of the arrangement, movement and energy of the particles
